[[uk:Список областей України]]","rewrite adding modern, historical regions",Mzajac,2005-05-27T22:28:40Z,"The change made is the addition of a section titled ""Traditional regions"" and ""Other historic regions,"" which includes a detailed list of various regions of Ukraine, both within and outside modern Ukraine, along with their historical significance.

Justification: The inclusion of specific historical regions and their cultural identifiers can be seen as an attempt to reinforce a narrative of Ukrainian identity and heritage, particularly in the context of ongoing geopolitical tensions. This framing may serve to assert claims over these regions in the face of external narratives, thus potentially weaponizing cultural heritage.",Weaponised

A list of the various '''regions of [[Ukraine]]''' and/or inhabited by [[Ukrainians]] and their ancestors throughout history.

-Administratively, Ukraine is currently subdivided into twenty-four [[oblast]]s (''oblasti'', [[province]]s), one [[autonomous republic]] (''avtonomna respublika''), and two cities (''mista'', singular ''misto'') with special legal status.
The traditional names of the regions of Ukraine are important geographic, historical, and ethnographic identifiers.

column2: ''Malorossiya'' or ''Malaya Rus'''}}), the name applied to Ukraine under the [[Russian Empire]] and earlier. Also, for historic reasons (note: left-bank and right bank refer to the bank of the river when facing downstream):

column1: ** [[Right-bank Ukraine]] (''Pravoberezhna Ukrayina'' or ''Pravoberezhzhia''), west of the [[Dnieper river]]
** [[Left-bank Ukraine]] (''Livoberezhna Ukrayina'' or ''Livoberezhzhia''), east of the Dnieper.

Here is a list of what constitutes such nominations:

column1: +Due to geopolitical, historical, and cultural factors, there are semi-official nominations to a certain region. The map right shows the broad sense of particular regions. The terms West, East, South and Central Ukraine are often used. There is no clear description on what includes/excludes one region or another, but rather a general reference. Here is a list of what constitutes such nominations:
+*Western Ukraine, may mean either the historic region of Galicia, or may also include Volhynia, Podolia, Transcarpathia, and/or Bukovina.
+*Eastern Ukraine may mean either the Don basin, Sloboda Ukraine, continental Taurida regions etc.

+*South Ukraine is often includes the whole Taurida, the Kryvyi Rih basin, and the regions of Mykolayiv and Odessa oblasts. Alternatively it may include the Don basin, in particularly the adjacent land to the Azov Sea.
+*Central Ukraine is more vague term and often denotes what is not included in Western or South-Eastern definitions.
+Other terms are rarely used such as South-West Ukraine, which can denote either [[Carpathian Ruthenia
column2: Transcarpathia]], or [[Budjak]]. Sometimes the term [[South-Eastern Ukraine]] is used to define both regions of the Southern and Eastern Ukraine. Due to the shape of the country, in narrow definition, term Northern Ukraine is often used to denote either the bulge of [[Chernihiv Oblast
column3: Chernihiv]]/[[Sumy Oblast]]s or, in broader terms, the whole of [[Polesia]]. North-western Ukraine almost exclusively refers to the historic region of [[Volhynia]]. This makes the term North-Eastern Ukraine rarest of them all, and is either used as synonym for the narrow definition of Northern Ukraine, or as synonym for Sloboda Ukraine (particularly the [[Sumy Oblast]]).

column2: ''Malorossiya'' or ''Malaya Rus'''}}), the name applied to Ukraine under the [[Russian Empire]]. Also, for historic reasons (note: left-bank and right bank refer to the bank of the river when facing downstream):

column1: ** [[Right-bank Ukraine]] (''Pravoberezhna Ukrayina'' or ''Pravoberezhzhia''), west of the [[Dnieper river]]",/* Traditional regions */ update,Aleksandr Grigoryev,2011-01-21T12:22:20Z,"**Added new section on ""Regions of Ukraine"" with detailed descriptions of various regions and their historical context.**
Not Weaponised. The content appears to provide a neutral geographical and historical overview of regions within Ukraine without employing loaded or politically charged language.",Not Weaponised

column1: Due to geopolitical, historical, and cultural factors, there are semi-official nominations to a certain region. The map right shows the broad sense of particular regions. The terms West, East, South and Central Ukraine are often used. There is no clear description on what includes/excludes one region or another, but rather a general reference. Here is a list of what constitutes such nominations:
-*Western Ukraine, may mean either the historic region of Galicia, or may also include Volhynia, Podolia, Transcarpathia, and/or Bukovina.
-*Eastern Ukraine may mean either the Don basin, Sloboda Ukraine, continental Taurida regions etc.

-*South Ukraine is often includes the whole Taurida, the Kryvyi Rih basin, and the regions of Mykolayiv and Odessa oblasts. Alternatively it may include the Don basin, in particularly the adjacent land to the Azov Sea.
-*Central Ukraine is more vague term and often denotes what is not included in Western or South-Eastern definitions.
+*Western Ukraine, may mean either the historic region of Galicia, or may also include Volhynia, Podolia, Transcarpathia, and/or Bukovina.
+*Eastern Ukraine may mean either the Don basin, Sloboda Ukraine, continental Taurida regions etc.

+*South Ukraine is often includes the whole Taurida, the Kryvyi Rih basin, and the regions of Mykolayiv and Odessa oblasts. Alternatively it may include the Don basin, in particularly the adjacent land to the Azov Sea.
+*Central Ukraine is more vague term and often denotes what is not included in Western or South-Eastern definitions.
Other terms are rarely used such as South-West Ukraine, which can denote either [[Carpathian Ruthenia
column2: Transcarpathia]], or [[Budjak]]. Sometimes the term [[South-Eastern Ukraine]] is used to define both regions of the Southern and Eastern Ukraine. Due to the shape of the country, in narrow definition, term Northern Ukraine is often used to denote either the bulge of [[Chernihiv Oblast
column3: Chernihiv]]/[[Sumy Oblast]]s or, in broader terms, the whole of [[Polesia]]. North-western Ukraine almost exclusively refers to the historic region of [[Volhynia]]. This makes the term North-Eastern Ukraine rarest of them all, and is either used as synonym for the narrow definition of Northern Ukraine, or as synonym for Sloboda Ukraine (particularly the [[Sumy Oblast]]).

column1: == References ==",what is a pseudo-state?,195.225.130.130,2010-04-07T08:22:08Z,"The change made in this revision involves the removal of the phrase ""pseudo-state until 1945"" from the entry for the ""Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic"" and the addition of a new entry for the ""Galician Soviet Socialist Republic.""

**Justification**: The term ""pseudo-state"" can carry a negative connotation, suggesting illegitimacy or lack of sovereignty, which may reflect a particular political narrative. The removal of this term could be seen as an attempt to reframe the historical context of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic in a more favorable light, while the addition of the Galician Soviet Socialist Republic provides further historical context.
**Conclusion**: Not Weaponised. The changes appear to be more about historical accuracy and context rather than promoting a specific political agenda or narrative.",Not Weaponised

column1: Due to geopolitical, historical, and cultural factors, there are semi-official nominations to a certain region. The map right shows the broad sense of particular regions. The terms West, East, South and Central Ukraine are often used. There is no clear description on what includes/excludes one region or another, but rather a general reference. Here is a list of what constitutes such nominations:
-*Western Ukraine, may mean either the historic region of Galicia, or may also include Volhynia, Podolia, Transcarpathia, and/or Bukovina.
-*Eastern Ukraine may mean either the Don basin, Sloboda Ukraine, continental Taurida regions etc.

-*South Ukraine is often includes the whole Taurida, the Kryvyi Rih basin, and the regions of Mykolayiv and Odessa oblasts. Alternatively it may include the Don basin, in particularly the adjacent land to the Azov Sea.
-*Central Ukraine is more vague term and often denotes what is not included in Western or South-Eastern definitions.
+*[[Western Ukraine]], may mean either the historic region of Galicia, or may also include Volhynia, Podolia, Transcarpathia, and/or Bukovina.
+*[[Eastern Ukraine]] may mean either the Don basin, Sloboda Ukraine, continental Taurida regions etc.

+*[[South Ukraine]] is often includes the whole Taurida, the Kryvyi Rih basin, and the regions of Mykolayiv and Odessa oblasts. Alternatively it may include the Don basin, in particularly the adjacent land to the Azov Sea.
+*[[Central Ukraine]] is more vague term and often denotes what is not included in Western or South-Eastern definitions.
Other terms are rarely used such as South-West Ukraine, which can denote either [[Carpathian Ruthenia
column2: Transcarpathia]], or [[Budjak]]. Sometimes the term [[South-Eastern Ukraine]] is used to define both regions of the Southern and Eastern Ukraine. Due to the shape of the country, in narrow definition, term Northern Ukraine is often used to denote either the bulge of [[Chernihiv Oblast
column3: Chernihiv]]/[[Sumy Oblast]]s or, in broader terms, the whole of [[Polesia]]. North-western Ukraine almost exclusively refers to the historic region of [[Volhynia]]. This makes the term North-Eastern Ukraine rarest of them all, and is either used as synonym for the narrow definition of Northern Ukraine, or as synonym for Sloboda Ukraine (particularly the [[Sumy Oblast]]).

'''Regions of Ukraine''' Ukraine is subdivided into 24 regions (''oblasti'', singular - ''oblast'''), 1 autonomous republic (''avtomnaya respublika'') in the [[Crimea]], and 2 municipalities (''mista'', singular - ''misto'') with regional status, marked by a *:
* [[Cherkasy region|Cherkasy]] * [[Chernihiv region|Chernihiv]] * [[Chernivtsi region|Chernivtsi]] * [[Dnipropetrovs'k region|Dnipropetrovs'k]] * [[Donets'k region|Donets'k]] * [[Ivano-Frankivs'k region|Ivano-Frankivs'k]] * [[Kharkiv region|Kharkiv]] * [[Kherson region|Kherson]] * [[Khmel'nyts'kyy region|Khmel'nyts'kyy]] * [[Kirovohrad region|Kirovohrad]] * [[Kiev]] * * [[Kiev region]] * [[Luhans'k region|Luhans'k]] * [[L'viv region|L'viv]] * [[Mykolayiv region|Mykolayiv]] * [[Odessa region|Odessa]] * [[Poltava region|Poltava]] * [[Republic of Crimea]] * [[Rivne region|Rivne]] * [[Sevastopol]] * * [[Sumy region|Sumy]] * [[Ternopil' region|Ternopil']] * [[Vinnytsya pregion|Vinnytsya]] * [[Volyn region|Volyn]] * [[Zakarpattya region|Zakarpattya]] * [[Zaporizhzhya region|Zaporizhzhya]] * [[Zhytomyr region|Zhytomyr]],"---
The traditional names of the regions of Ukraine are important geographic, historical, and ethnographic identifiers.
+*** [[Right-bank Ukraine]] (east of Zhytomyr Oblast, Kiev Oblast, Cherkasy Oblast), Central Ukraine
+*** [[Polesia]], Land of Turov (north of Kiev Oblast, east of Brest Oblast, west of Gomel Oblast), Northern Ukraine
+** Land of Pereyaslav (predominantly Poltava Oblast and east of Kiev Oblast), southern part of [[Left-bank Ukraine]], Little Russia, Central Ukraine
+* Land of Chernihiv (predominantly Chernihiv Oblast, west of Bryansk Oblast, east of Gomel Oblast), northern part of [[Left-bank Ukraine]], Little Russia, Northern Ukraine
+* [[Severia]] (Sumy Oblast, Kharkiv Oblast, Kursk Oblast, Belgorod Oblast)
+* Ruthenia, Kingdom of Rus, Western Ukraine, Western Oblast, Liitle Poland
+** [[Volhynia]] (Volyn Oblast, Rivne Oblast, west of Zhytomyr Oblast, north of Ternopil Oblast, north of Khmelnytsky Oblast), former principality
+** [[Chełm]], [[Belz]], [[San River]], [[Peremyshl]] (east of Podkarpackie Voivodeship and Lublin Voivodeship), former principality and a constituent land of Ruthenia
+** Berestia (west of Brest Oblast, south of Podlaskie Voivodeship)

column2: Galicia]] (Lviv Oblast, Ivano-Frankivsk Oblast, Ternopil Oblast)

column1: +* [[Podolia]] (Khmelnytsky Oblast, Vinnytsia Oblast, north of Odessa Oblast, west of Kirovohrad Oblast), Little Poland

column2: Zaporizhzhia]] (Dnipropetrovsk Oblast, east of Kirovohrad Oblast), New Serbia, Central Ukraine

column1: +* Pontic steppe, Wild Fields, New Russia
+** [[Donbass]] (""Donets Basin"") (Donetsk Oblast, Luhanks Oblast), also known as Cuman Land, Slavo-Serbia, Eastern Ukraine
+** Azov Littoral (Zaporizhia Oblast, south of Donetsk Oblast, southwest of Rostov Oblast)
+*** Over-Buh, Yedisan, Transnistria (Odessa Oblast, Mykolaiv Oblast)

column2: Transcarpathia / Carpathian Ruthenia]], Subcarpathian Rus, [[Carpatho-Ukraine]] and many others

column1: Regions historically inhabited by Ukrainians (mostly with other nations), which are partly or wholly outside modern Ukraine:
+* [[Kuban]] granted to Black Sea Cossacks colonization from the Russian government during the Russian-Circassian War

* [[Siberia]] (city of Omsk, [[Grey Ukraine]])",/* Traditional regions */ update,Aleksandr Grigoryev,2013-10-05T18:54:40Z,"The change involves the addition of multiple traditional region names and descriptions related to Ukraine, including terms like ""Land of Kiev,"" ""Little Poland,"" and ""New Russia,"" among others.

Justification: The inclusion of terms such as ""Little Russia"" and ""New Russia"" reflects a narrative that can be associated with Russian historical claims and perspectives on Ukrainian territories, potentially undermining Ukrainian sovereignty and identity.",Weaponised

*[[South Ukraine]] is often includes the whole Taurida, the Kryvyi Rih basin, and the regions of Mykolayiv and Odessa oblasts. Alternatively it may include the Don basin, in particularly the adjacent land to the Azov Sea.
*[[Central Ukraine]] is more vague term and often denotes what is not included in Western or South-Eastern definitions.
-Other terms are rarely used such as South-West Ukraine, which can denote either [[Carpathian Ruthenia
column2: Transcarpathia]], or [[Budjak]]. Sometimes the term [[South-Eastern Ukraine]] is used to define both regions of the Southern and Eastern Ukraine. Due to the shape of the country, in narrow definition, term Northern Ukraine is often used to denote either the bulge of [[Chernihiv Oblast
column3: Chernihiv]]/[[Sumy Oblast]]s or, in broader terms, the whole of [[Polesia]]. North-western Ukraine almost exclusively refers to the historic region of [[Volhynia]]. This makes the term North-Eastern Ukraine rarest of them all, and is either used as synonym for the narrow definition of Northern Ukraine, or as synonym for Sloboda Ukraine (particularly the [[Sumy Oblast]]).MARIA OZAWA

column1: -Due to geopolitical, historical, and cultural factors, there are semi-official nominations to a certain region. The map right shows the broad sense of particular regions. The terms West, East, South and Central Ukraine are often used. There is no clear description on what includes/excludes one region or another, but rather a general reference. Here is a list of what constitutes such nominations:
-*[[Western Ukraine]], may mean either the historic region of Galicia, or may also include Volhynia, Podolia, Transcarpathia, and/or Bukovina.

+Geopolitical, historical, and cultural factors play a role in assigning different areas of Ukraine to semi-official regions. The map on the right shows the approximate locations of some broad-brush regions. The terms ""West Ukraine"", ""East Ukraine"", ""South Ukraine"" and ""Central Ukraine"" occur in common usage. There is no clear definition of the boundaries of such regions, but rather a general reference. Lists of what may constitute such regions might include:
+*[[Western Ukraine]] may mean either the historic region of Galicia, or may also include Volhynia, Podolia, Transcarpathia, and/or Bukovina.
*[[Eastern Ukraine]] may mean either the Don basin, Sloboda Ukraine, continental Taurida regions etc.

-*[[South Ukraine]] is often includes the whole Taurida, the Kryvyi Rih basin, and the regions of Mykolayiv and Odessa oblasts. Alternatively it may include the Don basin, in particularly the adjacent land to the Azov Sea.
-*[[Central Ukraine]] is more vague term and often denotes what is not included in Western or South-Eastern definitions.

+*[[South Ukraine]] often includes the whole Taurida, the Kryvyi Rih basin, and the regions of Mykolayiv and Odessa oblasts. Alternatively it may include the Don basin, in particularly the adjacent land to the Azov Sea.
+*[[Central Ukraine]], a more vague term, often denotes what is not included in Western or South-Eastern definitions.
-Other terms are rarely used such as South-West Ukraine, which can denote either [[Carpathian Ruthenia
column2: Transcarpathia]], or [[Budjak]]. Sometimes the term [[South-Eastern Ukraine]] is used to define both regions of the Southern and Eastern Ukraine. Due to the shape of the country, in narrow definition, term Northern Ukraine is often used to denote either the bulge of [[Chernihiv Oblast
column3: Chernihiv]]/[[Sumy Oblast]]s or, in broader terms, the whole of [[Polesia]]. North-western Ukraine almost exclusively refers to the historic region of [[Volhynia]]. This makes the term North-Eastern Ukraine rarest of them all, and is either used as synonym for the narrow definition of Northern Ukraine, or as synonym for Sloboda Ukraine (particularly the [[Sumy Oblast]]).

column2: Transcarpathia]], or [[Budjak]]. Sometimes the term ""[[South-Eastern Ukraine]]"" is used to define both regions of the Southern and Eastern Ukraine. Due to the shape of the country, in narrow definition, term ""Northern Ukraine"" is often used to denote either the bulge of [[Chernihiv Oblast
column3: Chernihiv]]/[[Sumy Oblast]]s or, in broader terms, the whole of [[Polesia]]. ""North-western Ukraine"" almost exclusively refers to the historic region of [[Volhynia]]. This makes the term ""North-Eastern Ukraine"" rarest of them all - it is either used as synonym for the narrow definition of Northern Ukraine, or as synonym for Sloboda Ukraine (particularly the [[Sumy Oblast]]).

*[[South Ukraine]] often includes the whole Taurida, the Kryvyi Rih basin, and the regions of Mykolayiv and Odessa oblasts. Alternatively it may include the Don basin, in particularly the adjacent land to the Azov Sea.
*[[Central Ukraine]], a more vague term, often denotes what is not included in Western or South-Eastern definitions.
-Other terms are rarely used - such as ""South-West Ukraine"", which can denote either [[Carpathian Ruthenia
column2: Transcarpathia]], or [[Budjak]]. Sometimes the term ""[[South-Eastern Ukraine]]"" is used to define both regions of the Southern and Eastern Ukraine. Due to the shape of the country, in narrow definition, term ""Northern Ukraine"" is often used to denote either the bulge of [[Chernihiv Oblast
column3: Chernihiv]]/[[Sumy Oblast]]s or, in broader terms, the whole of [[Polesia]]. ""North-western Ukraine"" almost exclusively refers to the historic region of [[Volhynia]]. This makes the term ""North-Eastern Ukraine"" rarest of them all - it is either used as synonym for the narrow definition of Northern Ukraine, or as synonym for Sloboda Ukraine (particularly the [[Sumy Oblast]]).

The traditional names of the regions of Ukraine are important geographic, historical, and ethnographic identifiers.
-*** [[Right-bank Ukraine]] (east of Zhytomyr Oblast, Kiev Oblast, Cherkasy Oblast), Central Ukraine
-*** [[Polesia]], Land of Turov (north of Kiev Oblast, east of Brest Oblast, west of Gomel Oblast), Northern Ukraine

* [[Central Rada]] of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] (1917–1918)",update after move of Kiev→[[Kyiv]],Mzajac,2020-09-19T03:25:03Z,"The change made in this revision is the replacement of ""Kiev"" with ""Kyiv"" in multiple instances, as well as changing ""Kievan Rus'"" to ""Kyivan Rus"".

**Weaponised**: The use of ""Kyiv"" instead of ""Kiev"" aligns with the Ukrainian government's efforts to promote the use of the Ukrainian language and its cultural identity, especially in the context of the ongoing conflict with Russia. This change reflects a shift towards recognizing and asserting Ukrainian heritage, which can be seen as a form of cultural resistance against Russian narratives.",Weaponised

* [[Cherkasy region|Cherkasy]] * [[Chernihiv region|Chernihiv]] * [[Chernivtsi region|Chernivtsi]] * [[Dnipropetrovs'k region|Dnipropetrovs'k]] * [[Donets'k region|Donets'k]] * [[Ivano-Frankivs'k region|Ivano-Frankivs'k]] * [[Kharkiv region|Kharkiv]] * [[Kherson region|Kherson]] * [[Khmel'nyts'kyy region|Khmel'nyts'kyy]] * [[Kirovohrad region|Kirovohrad]] * [[Kiev]] * * [[Kiev region]] * [[Luhans'k region|Luhans'k]] * [[L'viv region|L'viv]] * [[Mykolayiv region|Mykolayiv]] * [[Odessa region|Odessa]] * [[Poltava region|Poltava]] * [[Republic of Crimea]] * [[Rivne region|Rivne]] * [[Sevastopol]] * * [[Sumy region|Sumy]] * [[Ternopil' region|Ternopil']] * [[Vinnytsya pregion|Vinnytsya]] * [[Volyn region|Volyn]] * [[Zakarpattya region|Zakarpattya]] * [[Zaporizhzhya region|Zaporizhzhya]] * [[Zhytomyr region|Zhytomyr]],"---
The traditional names of the regions of Ukraine are important geographic, historical, and ethnographic identifiers.
*** [[Right-bank Ukraine]] (east of Zhytomyr Oblast, Kiev Oblast, Cherkasy Oblast), Central Ukraine
*** [[Polesia]], Land of Turov (north of Kiev Oblast, east of Brest Oblast, west of Gomel Oblast), Northern Ukraine
** Land of Pereyaslav (predominantly Poltava Oblast and east of Kiev Oblast), southern part of [[Left-bank Ukraine]], Little Russia, Central Ukraine
-* Land of Chernihiv (predominantly Chernihiv Oblast, west of Bryansk Oblast, east of Gomel Oblast), northern part of [[Left-bank Ukraine]], Little Russia, Northern Ukraine

** [[Donbass]] (""Donets Basin"") (Donetsk Oblast, Luhanks Oblast), also known as Cuman Land, Slavo-Serbia, Eastern Ukraine",/* Traditional regions */ update,Aleksandr Grigoryev,2014-05-08T02:08:50Z,"The change made is the addition of images (file references) next to the names of various traditional regions in Ukraine, specifically for ""Land of Kiev,"" ""Land of Chernihiv,"" ""Ruthenia,"" ""Volhynia,"" ""Galicia,"" and ""Podolia.""

The inclusion of images alongside traditional region names can serve to visually emphasize and legitimize these regions' cultural significance, potentially reinforcing nationalistic narratives. This could be interpreted as an attempt to assert a specific cultural identity in the context of ongoing geopolitical tensions.",Weaponised

'''Regions of Ukraine''' Ukraine is subdivided into 24 regions (''oblasti'', singular - ''oblast'''), 1 autonomous republic (''avtomnaya respublika'') in the [[Crimea]], and 2 municipalities (''mista'', singular - ''misto'') with regional status, marked by a *:
* [[Cherkasy region|Cherkasy]] * [[Chernihiv region|Chernihiv]] * [[Chernivtsi region|Chernivtsi]] * [[Dnipropetrovs'k region|Dnipropetrovs'k]] * [[Donets'k region|Donets'k]] * [[Ivano-Frankivs'k region|Ivano-Frankivs'k]] * [[Kharkiv region|Kharkiv]] * [[Kherson region|Kherson]] * [[Khmel'nyts'kyy region|Khmel'nyts'kyy]] * [[Kirovohrad region|Kirovohrad]] * [[Kiev]] * * [[Kiev region]] * [[Luhans'k region|Luhans'k]] * [[L'viv region|L'viv]] * [[Mykolayiv region|Mykolayiv]] * [[Odessa region|Odessa]] * [[Poltava region|Poltava]] * [[Republic of Crimea]] * [[Rivne region|Rivne]] * [[Sevastopol]] * * [[Sumy region|Sumy]] * [[Ternopil' region|Ternopil']] * [[Vinnytsya pregion|Vinnytsya]] * [[Volyn region|Volyn]] * [[Zakarpattya region|Zakarpattya]] * [[Zaporizhzhya region|Zaporizhzhya]] * [[Zhytomyr region|Zhytomyr]],"---

* [[Southern Ukraine]] often includes the whole Taurida, the Kryvyi Rih basin, and the regions of Mykolayiv and Odessa oblasts. Alternatively it may include the Don basin, in particularly the adjacent land to the Azov Sea.
* [[Western Ukraine]] may mean either the historic region of Galicia, or may also include Volhynia, Podolia, Transcarpathia, and/or Bukovina.
-Other terms are rarely used - such as ""South-West Ukraine"", which can denote either [[Carpathian Ruthenia
column2: Transcarpathia]], or [[Budjak]]. Sometimes the term ""South-Eastern Ukraine"" is used to define both regions of the Southern and Eastern Ukraine. Due to the shape of the country, in narrow definition, term ""Northern Ukraine"" is often used to denote either the bulge of [[Chernihiv Oblast
column3: Chernihiv]]/[[Sumy Oblast]]s or, in broader terms, the whole of [[Polesia]]. ""North-western Ukraine"" almost exclusively refers to the historic region of [[Volhynia]]. This makes the term ""North-Eastern Ukraine"" rarest of them all - it is either used as synonym for the narrow definition of Northern Ukraine, or as synonym for Sloboda Ukraine (particularly the [[Sumy Oblast]]).

column1: +Other terms are rarely used – such as ""South-West Ukraine"", which can denote either [[Carpathian Ruthenia

column3: Chernihiv]]/[[Sumy Oblast]]s or, in broader terms, the whole of [[Polesia]]. ""North-western Ukraine"" almost exclusively refers to the historic region of [[Volhynia]]. This makes the term ""North-Eastern Ukraine"" rarest of them all – it is either used as synonym for the narrow definition of Northern Ukraine, or as synonym for Sloboda Ukraine (particularly the [[Sumy Oblast]]).

column1: Geopolitical, historical, and cultural factors play a role in assigning different areas of Ukraine to semi-official regions. The map on the right shows the approximate locations of some broad-brush regions. The terms ""West Ukraine"", ""East Ukraine"", ""South Ukraine"" and ""Central Ukraine"" occur in common usage. There is no clear definition of the boundaries of such regions, but rather a general reference. Lists of what may constitute such regions might include:
-*[[Western Ukraine]] may mean either the historic region of Galicia, or may also include Volhynia, Podolia, Transcarpathia, and/or Bukovina.
-*[[Eastern Ukraine]] may mean either the Don basin, Sloboda Ukraine, continental Taurida regions etc.

-*[[South Ukraine]] often includes the whole Taurida, the Kryvyi Rih basin, and the regions of Mykolayiv and Odessa oblasts. Alternatively it may include the Don basin, in particularly the adjacent land to the Azov Sea.
-*[[Central Ukraine]], a more vague term, often denotes what is not included in Western or South-Eastern definitions.
+* [[Central Ukraine]], a more vague term, often denotes what is not included in Western or South-Eastern definitions.
+* [[Eastern Ukraine]] may mean either the Don basin, Sloboda Ukraine, continental Taurida regions etc.

+* [[Southern Ukraine]] often includes the whole Taurida, the Kryvyi Rih basin, and the regions of Mykolayiv and Odessa oblasts. Alternatively it may include the Don basin, in particularly the adjacent land to the Azov Sea.
+* [[Western Ukraine]] may mean either the historic region of Galicia, or may also include Volhynia, Podolia, Transcarpathia, and/or Bukovina.
Other terms are rarely used - such as ""South-West Ukraine"", which can denote either [[Carpathian Ruthenia
column2: Transcarpathia]], or [[Budjak]]. Sometimes the term ""South-Eastern Ukraine"" is used to define both regions of the Southern and Eastern Ukraine. Due to the shape of the country, in narrow definition, term ""Northern Ukraine"" is often used to denote either the bulge of [[Chernihiv Oblast
column3: Chernihiv]]/[[Sumy Oblast]]s or, in broader terms, the whole of [[Polesia]]. ""North-western Ukraine"" almost exclusively refers to the historic region of [[Volhynia]]. This makes the term ""North-Eastern Ukraine"" rarest of them all - it is either used as synonym for the narrow definition of Northern Ukraine, or as synonym for Sloboda Ukraine (particularly the [[Sumy Oblast]]).

'''Regions of Ukraine''' Ukraine is subdivided into 24 regions (''oblasti'', singular - ''oblast'''), 1 autonomous republic (''avtomnaya respublika'') in the [[Crimea]], and 2 municipalities (''mista'', singular - ''misto'') with regional status, marked by a *:
* [[Cherkasy region|Cherkasy]] * [[Chernihiv region|Chernihiv]] * [[Chernivtsi region|Chernivtsi]] * [[Dnipropetrovs'k region|Dnipropetrovs'k]] * [[Donets'k region|Donets'k]] * [[Ivano-Frankivs'k region|Ivano-Frankivs'k]] * [[Kharkiv region|Kharkiv]] * [[Kherson region|Kherson]] * [[Khmel'nyts'kyy region|Khmel'nyts'kyy]] * [[Kirovohrad region|Kirovohrad]] * [[Kiev]] * * [[Kiev region]] * [[Luhans'k region|Luhans'k]] * [[L'viv region|L'viv]] * [[Mykolayiv region|Mykolayiv]] * [[Odessa region|Odessa]] * [[Poltava region|Poltava]] * [[Republic of Crimea]] * [[Rivne region|Rivne]] * [[Sevastopol]] * * [[Sumy region|Sumy]] * [[Ternopil' region|Ternopil']] * [[Vinnytsya pregion|Vinnytsya]] * [[Volyn region|Volyn]] * [[Zakarpattya region|Zakarpattya]] * [[Zaporizhzhya region|Zaporizhzhya]] * [[Zhytomyr region|Zhytomyr]],"---
Other terms are rarely used – such as ""South-western Ukraine"", which can denote either [[Carpathian Ruthenia
column2: Transcarpathia]], or [[Budjak]]. Sometimes the term ""South-eastern Ukraine"" is used to define both regions of the Southern and Eastern Ukraine. Due to the shape of the country, in narrow definition, term ""Northern Ukraine"" is often used to denote either the bulge of [[Chernihiv Oblast
column4: Sumy]] oblasts or, in broader terms, the whole of [[Polesia]]. ""North-western Ukraine"" almost exclusively refers to the historic region of [[Volhynia]]. This makes the term ""North-eastern Ukraine"" rarest of them all – it is either used as synonym for the narrow definition of Northern Ukraine, or as synonym for Sloboda Ukraine (particularly [[Sumy Oblast]]).

column1: Geopolitical, historical, and cultural factors play a role in assigning different areas of Ukraine to semi-official regions. The map on the right shows the approximate locations of some broad-brush regions. The terms ""Central Ukraine"", ""Eastern Ukraine"", ""Southern Ukraine"", and ""Western Ukraine"" occur in common usage. There is no clear definition of the boundaries of such regions, but rather a general reference. Lists of what may constitute such regions might include:

column1: Geopolitical, historical, and cultural factors play a role in assigning different areas of Ukraine to semi-official regions. The map on the right shows the approximate locations of some broad-brush regions. The terms ""Central Ukraine"", ""Eastern Ukraine"", ""Southern Ukraine"", and ""Western Ukraine"" occur in common usage. There is no clear definition of the boundaries of such regions, but rather a general reference. Lists of what may constitute such regions might include:",/* Regions of Ukraine */ rename,Mellk,2023-04-08T04:52:55Z,"Changed the section title from ""Regions of Ukraine"" to ""Contemporary regions"".
Not Weaponised. The change is a neutral rephrasing of a section title that does not introduce any loaded language or narratives related to cultural heritage weaponisation.",Not Weaponised

column1: * [[Central Ukraine]], a more vague term, often denotes what is not included in Western or South-Eastern definitions.
* [[Eastern Ukraine]] may mean either the Don basin, Sloboda Ukraine, continental Taurida regions etc.

-* [[Southern Ukraine]] often includes the whole Taurida, the Kryvyi Rih basin, and the regions of Mykolayiv and Odessa oblasts. Alternatively it may include the Don basin, in particularly the adjacent land to the Azov Sea.

+* [[Southern Ukraine]] often includes the whole Taurida, the Kryvyi Rih basin, and the regions of Mykolayiv and Odesa oblasts. Alternatively it may include the Don basin, in particularly the adjacent land to the Azov Sea.
* [[Western Ukraine]] may mean either the historic region of Galicia, or may also include Volhynia, Podolia, Transcarpathia, and/or Bukovina.
Other terms are rarely used – such as ""South-western Ukraine"", which can denote either [[Carpathian Ruthenia
column2: Transcarpathia]], or [[Budjak]]. Sometimes the term ""South-eastern Ukraine"" is used to define both regions of the Southern and Eastern Ukraine. Due to the shape of the country, in narrow definition, term ""Northern Ukraine"" is often used to denote either the bulge of [[Chernihiv Oblast
column4: Sumy]] oblasts or, in broader terms, the whole of [[Polesia]]. ""North-western Ukraine"" almost exclusively refers to the historic region of [[Volhynia]]. This makes the term ""North-eastern Ukraine"" rarest of them all – it is either used as synonym for the narrow definition of Northern Ukraine, or as synonym for Sloboda Ukraine (particularly [[Sumy Oblast]]).",,ITZQing,2023-04-24T19:16:19Z,"Changed ""Odessa Oblast"" to ""Odesa Oblast"" in multiple instances.

column1: Not Weaponised – The change is a correction of the spelling of a geographical name to align with the Ukrainian language's current standards, which does not carry any political or cultural weaponisation implications.",Not Weaponised

'''Regions of Ukraine''' Ukraine is subdivided into 24 regions (''oblasti'', singular - ''oblast'''), 1 autonomous republic (''avtomnaya respublika'') in the [[Crimea]], and 2 municipalities (''mista'', singular - ''misto'') with regional status, marked by a *:
* [[Cherkasy region|Cherkasy]] * [[Chernihiv region|Chernihiv]] * [[Chernivtsi region|Chernivtsi]] * [[Dnipropetrovs'k region|Dnipropetrovs'k]] * [[Donets'k region|Donets'k]] * [[Ivano-Frankivs'k region|Ivano-Frankivs'k]] * [[Kharkiv region|Kharkiv]] * [[Kherson region|Kherson]] * [[Khmel'nyts'kyy region|Khmel'nyts'kyy]] * [[Kirovohrad region|Kirovohrad]] * [[Kiev]] * * [[Kiev region]] * [[Luhans'k region|Luhans'k]] * [[L'viv region|L'viv]] * [[Mykolayiv region|Mykolayiv]] * [[Odessa region|Odessa]] * [[Poltava region|Poltava]] * [[Republic of Crimea]] * [[Rivne region|Rivne]] * [[Sevastopol]] * * [[Sumy region|Sumy]] * [[Ternopil' region|Ternopil']] * [[Vinnytsya pregion|Vinnytsya]] * [[Volyn region|Volyn]] * [[Zakarpattya region|Zakarpattya]] * [[Zaporizhzhya region|Zaporizhzhya]] * [[Zhytomyr region|Zhytomyr]],"---

* [[Southern Ukraine]] often includes the whole Taurida, the Kryvyi Rih basin, and the regions of Mykolayiv and Odesa oblasts. Alternatively it may include the Don basin, in particularly the adjacent land to the Azov Sea.
* [[Western Ukraine]] may mean either the historic region of Galicia, or may also include Volhynia, Podolia, Transcarpathia, and/or Bukovina.
-Other terms are rarely used – such as ""South-western Ukraine"", which can denote either [[Carpathian Ruthenia
column2: Transcarpathia]], or [[Budjak]]. Sometimes the term ""South-eastern Ukraine"" is used to define both regions of the Southern and Eastern Ukraine. Due to the shape of the country, in narrow definition, term ""Northern Ukraine"" is often used to denote either the bulge of [[Chernihiv Oblast
column4: Sumy]] oblasts or, in broader terms, the whole of [[Polesia]]. ""North-western Ukraine"" almost exclusively refers to the historic region of [[Volhynia]]. This makes the term ""North-eastern Ukraine"" rarest of them all – it is either used as synonym for the narrow definition of Northern Ukraine, or as synonym for Sloboda Ukraine (particularly [[Sumy Oblast]]).

column4: Sumy]] oblasts or, in broader terms, the whole of [[Polesia]]. ""North-western Ukraine"" almost exclusively refers to the historic region of [[Volhynia]]. This makes the term ""North-eastern Ukraine"" rarest of them all – it is either used as synonym for the narrow definition of Northern Ukraine, or as synonym for [[Sloboda Ukraine]] (particularly [[Sumy Oblast]]).

**Comment**: ""Only national states"" suggests a focus on entities that align with a specific national narrative, potentially downplaying or erasing the historical significance of Soviet-era Ukrainian governance.

**Analysis**: The removal of these entities could be seen as an attempt to reshape the historical narrative by excluding significant aspects of Ukraine's past that do not fit a singular nationalistic perspective. This aligns with a broader trend of weaponizing cultural heritage by selectively presenting history to support a specific political agenda.
